head.title: What if We Outgrow Our Environment?

hedline.hl1: What if We Outgrow Our Environment?

block.p: In "Baby Boom Boom" (editorial, April 24), you call last year's 4.179 million birthrate modest compared with the post-World War II birthrates of the Baby Boom era, and thus no cause for alarm. The birthrate may not be cause for alarm, but net population increase certainly is.

In "Baby Boom Boom" (editorial, April 24), you call last year's 4.179 million birthrate modest compared with the post-World War II birthrates of the Baby Boom era, and thus no cause for alarm. The birthrate may not be cause for alarm, but net population increase certainly is.

Have you forgotten your own exemplary April 11 coverage of the National Academy of Science's report calling for quick action on global warming? Your article quoted Daniel J. Evans, chairman of the Congressionally commissioned panel on global warming, who called population growth the "biggest single driver of atmospheric pollution."

Aside from the Soviet Union, the United States is the fastest growing industrialized country in the world. Although home to only 5 percent of the world's population, the United States generates 21 percent of the world's total carbon dioxide emissions, the major contributing gas to global warming.

The birth last year of 4.179 million American babies, more than any other year since 1961, greatly inhibits our ability to slow climate change. If we don't demonstrate a commitment to stopping population growth -- and with it a reduction in our air and other pollution -- we must be willing to accept the lion's share of responsibility for global warming and its grave repercussions. SUSAN WEBER Executive Director Zero Population Growth Washington, April 30, 1991
